2017}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'New Haven, CT', 'date': {'start': {'month': 8, 'day': None, 'year': 2011}, 'end': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2017}}, 'company': 'Yale University', 'description': 'My dissertation, “Christianity in Conflict: Religion and Conscience in France, 1940-1962,” explains how conscience became a tool of leftwing political dissidence in postwar France. I argue that during the Second World War, a vanguard of French Christian intellectuals and activists put forward a “resistance theology” that defined the conditions for legitimate disobedience to the state. By allowing individual Christians, both Catholic and Protestant, to act in conscience against authorities that enjoyed the support of the churches, resistance theology justified Christian aid to Jews at risk of deportation. I demonstrate, however, that the principle of conditional obedience to authority retained its political force even after 1944. During the Algerian War, dissident Christians rejected the dominant interpretation of Christianity, particularly Catholicism, as promoting unconditional obedience to the state. By denouncing the use of their religion in justifying torture and state violence, these Christians deprived the French state and its military and judicial institutions of a key moral endorsement for colonial repression. Through campaigns against economic exploitation and torture in Algeria, and in favor of legalizing conscientious objection during the Algerian War, Christian intellectuals, journalists, students, and humanitarian volunteers carved a political role for the individual conscience. This change was particularly revolutionary for French Catholics, long accustomed to hierarchical instruction on conscience; my dissertation traces the “Protestantization” of Catholic conscience in the decades before Vatican II as Catholics increasingly upheld individual resistance to authority. The changes that these Christians won in government policy and public opinion illustrate how ideas about rights emerged from the friction between anti-authoritarian activism and the conservative institutions of Church and State.', 'title': 'PhD, History Department', 'employment_type': None}, {'location': 'New Haven, CT', 'date': {'start': {'month': 8, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}, 'end':
